Panicum decaryanum
A. Camus in Bull. Soc. Bot. France 99: 65. 1952
.
Holotypus: MADAGASCAR . Prov. Fianarantsoa :
env. dâ€™Ambatofinandrahana ,
17.II.1938
,
Decary 13013
( P [ P00450263 ]!), syn. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph: Erect caespitose perennial, 20â€“70 cm tall, the culms glabrous or sparsely pubescent on nodes. Leaf sheaths glabrous. Ligule membranous, truncate. Leaf blades filiform, rolled, firm, 5â€“15 Ã— 0.1â€“0.2 cm , drying green-brown, basally sparsely pilose above. Panicles terminal, fully exserted, 5â€“10 cm long, ovate, the branches wiry, appressed to spreading, glabrous, the pedicels filiform and undulating, 2â€“10 mm long. Spikelets subglobose to ovate, apically acute, 1.5â€“1.8 mm long, usually purple or brown, gaping open at maturity. Lower glume 3/4â€“4/5 as long as the spikelet, obtuse to acute, with hyaline edges, 3â€“5-veined, pilose separated from the rest of the spikelet by an internode of c. 0.3 mm . Upper glume as long as the spikelet, herbaceous, 5-veined, pilose. Lower floret male, with palea. Lower lemma herbaceous, 5-veined, glabrous. Upper lemma shorter than the lower floret dull, finely verruculose, the small verruccae difficult to see without a microscope.

Distribution and ecology . â€“ Tropical African species; distribution in Madagascar limited to open seasonally flooded and grazed grassland and tapia forest on the High Plateau, 800â€“1800 m ( Fig. 16B ).

Notes . â€“ Recognisable by its filiform leaves, pilose spikelets, and a lower glume almost as long as the spikelet. The panicle resembles the sympatric
Panicum ibitense
and can be distinguished from that species by its erect tufted habit, basal leaves, and a lack of swollen underground storage organs.

Additional material examined . â€“
